title: Confusing test error message when `wantError` is not true

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

body:
If a test case has `wantError: false` (explicitly or not; `false` is the default) and the command being tested does throw an error, the error message can be pretty confusing. For example:

```diff
diff --git a/cmd/helm/lint_test.go b/cmd/helm/lint_test.go
index 3501ccf8..b03d9682 100644
--- a/cmd/helm/lint_test.go
+++ b/cmd/helm/lint_test.go
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@ func TestLintCmdWithSubchartsFlag(t *testing.T) {
                name:      "lint good chart with bad subcharts",
                cmd:       fmt.Sprintf("lint %s", testChart),
                golden:    "output/lint-chart-with-bad-subcharts.txt",
-               wantError: true,
+               wantError: false,
        }, {
                name:      "lint good chart with bad subcharts using --with-subcharts flag",
                cmd:       fmt.Sprintf("lint --with-subcharts %s", testChart),
```

```console
$ GO111MODULE=on go test  -run TestLint ./... -race
--- FAIL: TestLintCmdWithSubchartsFlag (0.15s)
    --- FAIL: TestLintCmdWithSubchartsFlag/lint_good_chart_with_bad_subcharts (0.07s)
        helm_test.go:61: running cmd (attempt 1): lint testdata/testcharts/chart-with-bad-subcharts
        helm_test.go:64: expected error, got '1 chart(s) linted, 1 chart(s) failed'
FAIL
FAIL	helm.sh/helm/v3/cmd/helm	0.315s
```

The reason seems to be the semantical mismatch between [this `if` statement](https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/47c2fd78a2b793f904ead0a9364ebec14814c271/cmd/helm/helm_test.go#L63:L65)'s antecedent (which is essentially an XOR expression) and its consequent (which doesn't acknowledge that):

```go
if (err != nil) != tt.wantError {
	t.Errorf("expected error, got '%v'", err)
}
```

(The exact same problem is present [here](https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/47c2fd78a2b793f904ead0a9364ebec14814c271/cmd/helm/helm_test.go#L85:L87), but I think `runTestActionCmd` should be removed anyway, as suggested in #10453.)
